title: The Android Invasion
dialogue_triumphs: 'Let's try the pub!' chuckles the Doctor. [Kraals drink McEwans Export.]
dialogue_disasters: 'I will now activate the hostility circuits.'
goofs: The Doctor lets go of a branch and it slaps Sarah in the face.
A large piece of cardboard appears behind the pod for the Doctor to lie on.
The Doctor's robot detector in episode four would have been very useful earlier on.
The Kraal plan has several flawed aspects: their indestructible androids' faces fall off when they trip, and their complete memory prints don't include a dislike for ginger pop.

The village, the Space Centre and all the people were copied from Crayford's mind, so why is there an android of Harry (he wasn't a member of UNIT two years previously), and why isn't there one of the Brigadier (who does, after all, have his own office at the Space Centre)?
Crayford has never looked under his eyepatch to find his intact eye! (And nobody at Space Control notices this acquisition, either.)
As the Daily Mail reviewer in 1975 wondered, how can the Doctor use his own android against Styggron if all the androids have been neutralized?

continuity_notes.name: The Doctor
continuity_notes.description: Time Lord protagonist, likes tea, muffins and ginger beer. Can survive high acceleration and was unpaid when advising UNIT.

continuity_notes.name: Sarah Jane Smith
continuity_notes.description: The Doctor's companion, a journalist for at least two years. Hates ginger pop and once came to Devesham on a story.

continuity_notes.name: Sergeant Benton
continuity_notes.description: UNIT soldier, has a younger sister who is his ballroom-dancing partner.

continuity_notes.name: TARDIS
continuity_notes.description: The Doctor's time and space machine, due for its 500-year service.

continuity_notes.name: Kraals
continuity_notes.description: Alien race attempting to invade Earth, aware of the Time Lords.

continuity_notes.name: Space Defence Station
continuity_notes.description: British installation against alien attack, the only one of its kind in the world.

continuity_notes.name: UNIT
continuity_notes.description: United Nations Intelligence Taskforce, dealing with extraterrestrial threats.
continuity_notes.current_status: Active, with staff present at the Space Defence Station

technobabble: The planet Oseidon has the highest natural radiation level in the galaxy, but an Earth-type atmosphere, gravity, etc.
roots: Star Trek (the mind probe in 'Errand of Mercy')

locations.name: Oseidon
locations.description: Home planet of the Kraals, with the highest natural radiation level in the galaxy but Earth-like conditions.
locations.current_status: Habitable by Kraals and seemingly by humans

locations.name: Devesham Space Defence Station
locations.description: British space defense installation, capable of rocket launches and landings.
locations.current_status: Operational, focus of Kraal invasion plan

locations.name: Devesham village
locations.description: Village near the Space Defence Station, replicated by the Kraals.
locations.current_status: Replica created as part of invasion plan

future_history: Humans have only got as far as orbiting Jupiter. Space freighters were being tested two years ago, suggesting the existence of space stations.
untold_adventures: The Doctor once met the Duke of Marlborough.
additional_notes: Fashion Victims: Styggron's silver Doc Martens. The android mechanics' space helmets. 'I don't like the look of them,' says Sarah.
bottom_line: 'Resistance is… inadvisable.' Stupid, tiresome and very irritating. Kenneth Williams' description of episode two in his diaries: 'Doctor Who gets more and more silly.'
